awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Hypervelocity Gradient Field Fusion
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a more rapid lower-cost development path to a commercially attractive highly modular fusion power plant. Although early stage in its conceptual development, this technology has the potential to leapfrog past current fuel cycle models to provide cheaper, advanced aneutronic fuel systems that reduce or eliminate neutron reaction products and may also eliminate the need for tritium. The abundance of fusion fuel from seawater could provide strategic energy security and economic security to the U.S. and allied nations by phasing out need for hostile foreign fossil fuel suppliers. The commercial impact of this project includes grid based clean fusion energy is literally could extend to a $T+ market if expanded to meet global power demand, with a market pull driven by the need for clean abundant inexpensive energy. This technology will support a wide range of science and engineering jobs, and manufacturing jobs in both the energy and aerospace industries. This project will perform computational modeling and analytical calculations to show scientific and engineering feasibility prior to a focused follow-on experimental development program.

This SBIR Phase 1 project proposes to research and develop a new, simpler, and cheaper approach to fusion energy for grid based electric power. In this approach, a small fusion fuel capsule is accelerated to 10 km/s and injected into the throat of a strong magnetic field coil where it is symmetrically crushed to ignite and burn the gaseous fusion fuel contained within. While conceptually appealing and straightforward, some key components are partially unproven and require extensive research to show feasibility. First, the fuel capsule implosion and resulting fusion burn are not yet studied in sufficient detail to understand the potential plasma physics problems, including plasma-wall interactions, end losses, preheat, and overall energy yield and gain. Second, the novel railgun design needs development with a plasma armature and distributed power input using mass-produced moderate voltage capacitors and solid-state switches in order to achieve the estimated 10 km/s required to induce fusion and long life-time components. Extensive computational modeling and analytical calculations and design will be performed to de-risk the concept and establish a point design for a Phase 2 experimental validation of the concept.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Magneto-Inertial Fusion (MIF) may result in significantly smaller reactors and enable near term development of fusion propulsion and energy production systems.  In MIF, a strong magnetic field is used to reduce cross-field thermal transport rates and enhance fusion-product charged-particle energy deposition within an imploded magnetized plasma-fuel target until fusion reactions occur.  Because of the potential for lower compression power compared to inertial confinement fusion and lower total stored energy compared to magnetic confinement, MIF may hold potential as a lower cost development path for commercial fusion power production.

The Gradient Field Fusion (GFF) concept, originally conceived at NASA for fusion propulsion, flips the theta-pinch concepts around and fires the fuel target at high speed into a stationary field with strong gradient. A target fired at high axial velocity into a strong converging magnetic field gradient will effectively experience a rapidly changing axial magnetic field and undergo a similar inductive compression as a stationary target at the center of a rapidly pulsed magnetic field. NearStar adapted this approach in the Hypervelocity Gradient Field Fusion (HGFF) concept by adding a Self-Augmented Railgun (SARG) to launch the fuel capsule repetitively at 10 km/s for terrestrial fusion power production.

This Phase 1 SBIR effort was focused on analyzing both the HGFF components/concept and the SARG launcher. As a result of analyzing the HGFF system, some technical hurdles of the HGFF approach for terrestrial power production were identified, mainly associated with the central high field coil and proper implosion of the fuel capsule. The HGFF concept gradually evolved into the present Magnetized Target Impact Fusion (MTIF) concept as a way of overcoming those problems. The SARG railgun driver originally proposed still remains the same, but the fuel capsule configuration evolved to a much more practical and commercially compelling design.

Multidimensional modeling of the HGFF target capsule led to the conclusion that heating and compression were limited due to complications with the capsule geometry. Additional difficulties included the unrealistically small gap required between the coil inner diameter and the capsule outer diameter. Irreproducible pointing accuracies could be expected to lead to catastrophic projectile impacts of the coil structure, clearly unacceptable. The NearStar/UAH team evolved the projectile/target design through a combination of literature review and analysis, leading to a new target design based on hypervelocity impact of a solid pusher into a cavity prefilled with deuterium (preferred) or a mixture of deuterium/tritium (backup).

Both HGFF and MTIF are variants of impact fusion. In the first, the fuel capsule impacts a magnetic field. This turned out to be difficult to implement for a commercially attractive powerplant. The HGFF concept gradually evolved into MTIF, impacting a similar but reconfigured high velocity fuel capsule onto a solid target with the magnetic field embedded within the fuel capsule rather than imposed from without. Magnetic flux trapping yields the possibility of generating much larger magnetic fields than were possible in the HGFF approach. A further refinement moves the magnetized target structure from a stationary object and instead mounts everything on the high velocity projectile, which slams into a flowing curtain of molten lead acting as a 'replaceable' backstop. We have thus moved the troublesome magnet coil of HGFF onto a tiny mass-produced coil on the fuel capsule itself. This provides a dramatic reduction in system complexity and is a truly elegant solution to achieving repetitive impact fusion.

Evolution of the new target design was guided by earlier work in the 1970’s and 80’s in impact fusion. A survey of modern inertial fusion concepts reveal a common technique of converting deposited energy into a quasi-spherical implosion to reach ignition. The NearStar approach evolved into a similar technique but with important distinctions. First, and most importantly, the cavity is pre-magnetized on impact using the kinetic energy of the projectile to drive the magnetizing current. This also provides the ability to ohmically preheat the target during implosion. Second, the presence of the magnetic field, which is amplified during implosion via flux compression, suppresses the cross-field electron thermal conduction, lowering the instantaneous power required and total reactor energy needed to reach breakeven. Finally, the driver is a highly innovative long life augmented railgun using off-the-shelf energy storage with relatively low voltage and significantly higher energy storage density. Operation of the SARG launcher was analyzed via circuit equation simulations to explore SARG performance capabilities leading to the conclusion that SARG appears capable of attaining >10 km/s and is ready for experimental development.

Collectively, the MTIF concept greatly lowers the size, cost, and complexity of a fusion reactor leading to a powerplant concept that can operate on pure DD, eliminating supply chain, safety, and complexity issues associated with a DT fusion economy.
